head.title: A Long, Hard Road For Tsunami Relief

identified-content.location: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

hedline.hl1: A Long, Hard Road For Tsunami Relief

abstract.p: Dr Daniel Kortsch letter holds that although tsunami relief work has been at times wasteful, one cannot underestimate blessing it can be for so many thousands

block.p: Re ''Where Tsunami Ravaged, Barely a Sign of Relief '' (front page, April 6):

Re ''Where Tsunami Ravaged, Barely a Sign of Relief '' (front page, April 6):

As a doctor working in Banda Aceh and Calang in Indonesia, I witnessed the daily waste of hundreds of tons of food and other aid. I saw a military leader try to appropriate a water filtration system for his personal shower, and each day I saw supplies being stolen as the United States military simply dumped food and water off its hovercraft and quickly left.

The aid that did reach the refugees, however, was much needed. The piles of coconuts attested to the dire need for fresh water before supplies arrived, and the long lines of patients needing medical care attested to the lack of medical services.
Although relief work has been at times wasteful, one cannot underestimate the blessing it can be for so many thousands.
